Table.Current Status / Notes: Spoke with seller. Passed. He judged the market as shrinking and the product as outdated. No LOI.
Passed after initial review. Said something felt off with the seller and it did not pass his sniff test.
Considered moving for it. A more suitable local buyer emerged and took it. He did not pursue further.
Reviewed. Retail model plus declining category. Not excited to run a counter-heavy store. Passed.

Table.Deal Name: Sacramento Traffic Signs Manufacturer + Real Estate
Table.Current Status / Notes: Attractive recurring replacement cycle. Required relocation and owner insisted on selling real estate at an inflated price. Numbers did not pencil. Passed.
Liked the end-of-life need and recurring nature. Not SBA-able and seller wanted all-cash. Passed.
Reviewed and found the B2B recurring angle compelling. Exploratory only. No further action noted.

Table.Deal Name: Framing and Carpentry Company — Riverside/Inland Empire, CA
Table.Current Status / Notes: Active modeling and LOI prep. Seller call went well; rapport remains strong. Broker (Scott) is very responsive and appears early in his career. Backlog letter shows three projected future jobs with Holland Construction/Holland Partners (Sunset Echo, Liberty, Magnolia), roughly high‑20s to ~$30M combined; several large jobs already awarded and started. Future backlog is concentrated with one builder; overall customer base is 2–4 customers. Pushkar adjusted SDE to ~ $800k to include ~$200k salary for the 10% partner who wants to stay employed long term; will keep purchase agreement language SBA‑compliant (seller/partner employment limited to 12 months on paper). Considering a creative, SBA‑compliant structure: cash at close in the ~2.0x–2.3x range of seller’s SDE, total consideration around ~3.5x–4.2x of Pushkar’s adjusted SDE, and a 20%–33% performance‑based, forgivable seller note tied pro rata to 2024 revenue or to project realization (not an earnout). Macro caution on multifamily/new‑build; hiring capacity to deliver backlog is a risk. Working capital/LOC use remains a concern. Next: Submit a formal LOI using the firm template by Monday (week of 2025‑10‑27), include normalized NWC set post‑diligence and performance‑note protection; may add a short intro video with the LOI.

Table.Deal Name: Large Machine Shop (Utah ops; owner in AZ)
Table.Current Status / Notes: Exploratory. Ryan spoke with broker. CIM shows ~$2M cash flow with an ask near ~7.5x; heavy PP&E with an estimated $10M liquidation value. Listed in AZ but operated in Utah; owner puts in ~5–10 hours/month; not a fully stacked management team. Price structure and asset base discussed; no next steps set.

Table.Deal Name: Local ABA Clinic (Autism therapy; Phoenix Metro)
Table.Current Status / Notes: LOI fully executed. Exclusivity 90 days + 30‑day mutual extension. $30k escrow payable at APA; excluding real estate (lease in place). Active risk review: about 96% Medicaid exposure across ABA (86% of ABA) and HCBS sides. Live Oak asked for reimbursement history and 2026 outlook; Pathward is interested; broker Ishan is running term sheets; Bruce (First Bank of the Lake) is waiting on balance sheets (seller delayed due to reconciling a large withdrawal). Pushkar requested fee schedules and reimbursement statements to see if MercyCare cuts have already hit. Considering re‑trade: move roughly half of the $1.5M seller note to full 10‑year standby and keep the rest performance‑based; also exploring a larger policy‑tied, forgivable note if rate cuts occur in 3–5 years. He obtained quotes: healthcare counsel ($5k retainer; $10k–$20k billed at close) and Treewalk QoE (~$13k; early fatal‑flaw no‑charge approach). Modeling shows DSCR risk if cuts land; may walk if structure cannot de‑risk. Late‑Dec updates: Pathward issued a term sheet; Live Oak sent a preliminary term sheet; multiple lenders asked that about $750k of the seller note be on full 10‑year standby; Live Oak currently wants two BCBAs on 5‑year employment agreements (no PG or equity). Site visit completed; will push re‑trade on seller notes using term sheets. Mid‑Jan: seller travel and slow responses; still waiting on billing reports and fee schedules. The state filed a motion to dismiss the Centria v. MercyCare case; governor’s budget due soon. Pushkar is mentally checked out; plans to push a re‑trade next week and set an end‑of‑January go/no‑go; Wendy (Live Oak) is back from vacation and he will brief lenders candidly.
Not selected. Seller entered exclusivity with another buyer. Our offer was competitive; broker said he would reach out if something changes.
Passed. Required near all‑cash close (~$700k; ~2x multiple) and relied on Google traffic/paid acquisition. Not SBA‑able. He does not want algorithm‑dependent lead flow.

Table.Deal Name: Healthcare IT Installations + MSP (Greater LA; hospitals)
Table.Current Status / Notes: LOI fully signed (early Jan 2026). Met seller (Sam) in person; strong rapport. Business is highly owner‑dependent: Sam handles most support, projects, and daily ops; 50% partner is passive. Seller is willing to stay 3–5 years at about $100k/year. Broker (Mo, Transworld) pushed a template APA and claimed LOI exclusivity is non‑binding; heavy gatekeeping of seller contact. Plan: use the 25‑day window to secure full financials and hold weekly seller calls, then revert to a normal sequence with a buyer‑drafted APA. Lenders: Jared (First Internet) asked for a full file once docs arrive; Tom Lyons (Byline) did a 1‑hour intro, is interested, and quoted Prime + ~2%, pending documents. Modeling: testing higher equity injection and a working‑capital tranche/LOC to fund 1–2 near‑shore hires in year one; small capex for hosted PBX expansion (Dallas/PA). Evaluating key‑person risk versus platform upside while keeping DSCR fundable.

Table.Deal Name: Commercial Landscaping Company (Phoenix area; Benchmark listing)
Table.Current Status / Notes: Reviewed. Broker reported seller conditions that disqualified us: no SBA, will not sell to an Arizona buyer, and wants substantially more than $12M. Passed.

What went well: Got to seller conversations quickly when deals looked interesting
Applied clear "needs vs wants" filter effectively
Identified macro and product risks early (shrinking markets, outdated tech)
Checked SBA eligibility upfront to avoid wasting time
Evaluated real estate impact on returns accurately
Built strong rapport with sellers when given the chance
Adjusted SDE properly to include fair pay for staying partners
Negotiated escrow terms to be refundable and count toward equity
Engaged multiple lenders early and in parallel
Secured two LOIs while maintaining viable parallel paths
Completed deep policy research on Medicaid risks
Pushed back successfully on rushed timelines and premature documents
Used live modeling to test higher equity and working capital to fund early hires while keeping DSCR
Challenges / freeze points: Broker gatekeeping and low NDA-to-CIM conversion rates
Energy drops after promising deals failed
Uncertainty around Arizona licensing requirements and qualifier structures
Real estate requirements complicated some deals
Working capital intensity made construction deal difficult
Concerned about new-construction exposure and cyclicality
California relocation friction due to family logistics
Medicaid concentration creating existential risk on ABA deal
Sellers slow to provide basic financials and rate documentation
Brokers pushing template APAs before diligence
Extreme owner dependence on MSP; seller does most day-to-day work (key person risk)
Learning curve: Reinforced preference for recurring/mandated replacement cycles
Clearer understanding of SBA eligibility requirements
Better grasp of real estate valuation and when buying kills returns
Importance of being local vs competing out-of-market
How to structure SBA-compliant performance-based seller notes
Need to normalize SDE when partners stay employed
Escrow mechanics and how to make them count toward equity
Legal/QoE sequencing for regulated healthcare businesses
Importance of payer mix in healthcare deals
Value of running parallel lender paths
How to push back on shortened diligence windows
When to walk away despite time invested
Using simple AI checks before paying for QoE on small deals (cash-to-books, working capital peg)
How to use higher equity and a working-capital line to fund early near-shore hires while protecting DSCR
Notes from transcripts/interactions: Biggest challenge is keeping momentum through highs and lows
Prefers not buying real estate unless fairly priced and necessary
Spouse fully supportive and will work full-time in acquired business
Will send broker-call questions to Slack for quick feedback
Wants the actual decision maker on calls, not just intermediaries
Won't submit LOIs without meeting seller first
Blocks "lunch" on calendar for acquisition calls due to employer visibility
Ready to walk if deal risk can't be shifted to structure
